title: Cross-Laminated Timber Is Building Skyscrapers
description: A quick win: understand Cross-Laminated Timber Is Building Skyscrapers.

hook.text: An 18-story wooden building stands in Norway. Cross-laminated timber (CLT) challenges concrete and steel for height.

buildup.text: CLT glues layers of lumber at 90Â° angles, like plywood but with full-size boards. The result is a massive panel.

discovery.text: CLT is 5x lighter than concrete with comparable strength. Lighter buildings need smaller foundations and less digging.

twist.text: Fire seems fatal for wood, but CLT chars predictably on the outside, insulating the core. It passes 2-hour fire tests.

climax.text: Trees absorb COâ‚‚ while growing, and CLT locks it into buildings. A CLT building stores carbon rather than emitting it.

punchline.text: Wooden skyscrapers: lighter, greener, and fireproof.

quiz.question: How does CLT perform in fire compared to expectations?
options: It chars on the outside, insulating the core and passing 2-hour fire ratings
